awd_titl_txt: Network and Distributed System Security Symposium 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal supports student participation in the 2021 Network and Distributed System Security (NDSS) Symposium held virtually in February 2021. NDSS brings together innovative and forward-thinking members of the Internet community who research, design, develop, and deploy the technologies that define network and distributed system security. This grant enables career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers. In the pandemic era, virtual attendance at conferences is crucial for jump-starting academic careers, and this award helps in that direction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The 28th annual Network and Distributed System Security (NDSS) Symposium was held virtually on February 21-25, 2021. The NDSS Symposium is an annual conference hosted by the Internet Society that brings together leaders in cyber security to facilitate collaboration and exchange among researchers and practitioners of network and distributed system security.

Due to COVID-19, this event was held virtually for the first time. This project supported the deployment of virtual technologies for the conference as well as funding to cover 15 graduate and undergraduate students from US based institutions. Participation in technical conferences like the NDSS plays a critical role in students? education, providing them the opportunity to interact with senior researchers and gain exposure to leading edge work in the field. Student participation is vital to preparing the next generation of Internet technical leaders to address rising threats to the security and resilience of the Internet.

The 2021 NDSS Symposium program (https://www.ndss-symposium.org/ndss-program/ndss-2021/) offered participants access to five days of programming including:

--- Six full-day workshops including AutoSec, BAR, CoronaDef, DNS Privacy, LASER, and MADWeb;
--- 21 sessions presenting 90 peer reviewed academic research papers;
--- A Monday keynote addressing Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Integrity by Diana L. Burley, Ph.D., Vice Provost for Research at American University;
--- A Wednesday keynote by Gavin O?Gorman of Symantec on the recent Solar Winds security incident;
--- A virtual poster session with 19 posters;
--- A replay session for easier participation for attendees in the Asia Pacific regions; and
--- A virtual networking track using Gather Town and Slack.

NDSS 2022 welcomed a total 769 registered participants with approximately half being students.
